Getting started with CI for R

Patrick Schratz, Kirill Müller

2018-07-25

Source: vignettes/tic.Rmd
tic.Rmd

Prerequisites

If you are completely unfamiliar with the term Continuous Integration (CI), we highly recommend to read the following ressources:

  • https://ropensci.github.io/dev_guide/ci.html
  • https://juliasilge.com/blog/beginners-guide-to-travis/
  • http://mahugh.com/2016/09/02/travis-ci-for-test-automation/

Now that you know that CI can help you a lot in R package development by automatically checking your package in a clean environmnent, you probably wonder what the tic package does do make the world even simpler.

Initialization

The easiest way to use tic for CI services is to call usethis::use_ci(). This will create templates for both “Travis CI” and “Appveyor” and initialize all the required authentication steps for deployment. The usethis package is used because it contains various other useful use_* functions that simplify R package development. The hard work in the background is actually done by the R packages travis and tic. See here for more detailed information on how tic, travis and usethis work together.

Setup

R packages

After having called usethis::use_ci() you will find .travis.yml, appveyor.yml and a tic.R file in your repo. The default template will trigger builds on both CI services that do the following:

  • Install required dependecies of the R package
  • Run rcmdcheck::rcmdcheck() on the package (see here for more details)
  • Build a pkgdown site and deploy it to the docs/ folder of the master branch (Travis only)
  • Run a code coverage on the package and upload it to codecov.io (Travis only)

The commands that are going to be executed in each stage of each service are specified in a centralised file tic.R - read here for a more thorough explanation of all advantages of tic.

Examples

tic can also be used for bookdown, blogdown, rmarkdown, drat, and packagedocs projects. It can also publish to figshare. See the example projects below for more information.

  • tic.blogdown
  • ŧic.bookdown
  • tic.drat
  • tic.R-package
  • tic.rmarkdown
  • tic.figshare.

Build lifecycle

Stages

CI services run builds in stages. Stages are ordered as follows:

  • before_install
  • install
  • after_install
  • before_script
  • script
  • after_success
  • after_failure
  • before_deploy
  • deploy
  • after_deploy
  • after_script

The after_xxx stages are only for notifications and will not fail a build. They are started conditionally, dependent on their name. For example stage after_success will only be run of if there was a successfull execution of the whole build process, i.e. no error in any stage. The after_deploy stage will only be run if there the deploy stage was run before.

tic also uses the stages approach and simply fowards all the commands that should be run in stage to the tic.R file where these will specified in an CI-agnostic way using R syntax.

before_install: 
  - R -q -e 'install.packages("remotes"); remotes::install_github("ropenscilabs/tic")
  - R -q -e 'tic::prepare_all_stages()'
install: R -q -e 'tic::install()'
after_install: R -q -e 'tic::after_install()'
before_script: R -q -e 'tic::before_script()'
script: R -q -e 'tic::script()'
after_success: R -q -e 'tic::after_success()'
after_failure: R -q -e 'tic::after_failure()'
before_deploy: R -q -e 'tic::before_deploy()'
deploy:
  provider: script
  script: R -q -e 'tic::deploy()'
  on:
    all_branches: true
after_deploy: R -q -e 'tic::after_deploy()'
after_script: R -q -e 'tic::after_script()'

In a nutshell, the workflow is like this:

.travis.yml/appveyor.yml -> tic.R -> commands to execute

The most important stage for tic is the before_install stage. Here, tic gets installed and runs prepare_all_stages(). This magical function makes sure that all subsequent steps can be executed, e.g. by installing required R packages. Note however that this is not the function that takes cares of installing dependencies of your R package but only to ensure that the commands specified in tic.R can be executed. The installation of R package dependencies is triggered by the wrapper function add_package_checks(). This wrapper function adds four important commands to specific stages in the build cycle:

  1. A call to utils::update.packages() with ask = FALSE in the “before_install” stage (only for non-interactive CIs)

  2. A call to remotes::install_deps() with dependencies = TRUE in the “install” stage

  3. A step_rcmdcheck() in the “script” stage, using the warnings_are_errors, notes_are_errors and args arguments

  4. A call to covr::codecov() in the “after_success” stage

If you specify these stages on your own in tic.R, the commands above will not be executed. So don’t forget to add the commands manually to make sure that everything works!

Note: All R packages that should be stored in the Travis cache for R packages should be either installed in the install or before_install stage. This applies for example to Github packages. See here for details.

Steps

Steps are essentially the commands that are executed in each stage. tic uses the pipe operator to chain steps in tic.R, for example

get_stage("deploy") %>%
  add_step(step_build_pkgdown())

This step is chained to stage “deploy” and subsequently only run in this stage. More steps that should be run in this stage could just by piped after the add_step(step_build_pkgdown()) step. Steps are usually defined using two nested commands: add_step() and the corrsponding step, here step_build_pkgdown().

The tic package defines the following steps:

  • step_hello_world: print “Hello, World!” to the console, helps testing a tic setup
  • step_rcmdcheck: run R CMD check via the rcmdcheck package
  • step_run_code: run arbitrary code, optionally run preparatory code and install dependent packages
    • add_step(step_run_code(...)) can be abbreviated with add_code_step(...)
  • step_install_ssh_key: make available a private SSH key (which has been added before to your project by usethis::use_travis_deploy())
  • step_test_ssh: test the SSH connection to GitHub, helps troubleshooting deploy problems
  • step_build_pkgdown: building package documentation via pkgdown
  • step_push_deploy: deploy to GitHub, with arguments:
    • path: which path to deploy, default: "."
    • branch: which branch to deploy to, default: ci()$get_branch()
    • orphan: should the branch consist of a single commit that contains all changes (TRUE), or should it be updated incrementally (FALSE, default)
      • You must specify a branch if you set orphan = TRUE
    • remote_url: the remote URL to push to, default: the URL related to the Travis run
    • commit_message: the commit message, will by default contain [ci skip] to avoid a loop, and useful information related to the CI run
    • commit_paths: Which path(s) to commit. Useful to only commit single files that have changed during the CI run.

What’s not covered yet?

  • SystemRequirements: tic is not yet capable of automatically determing system requirements specified in DESCRIPTION files of an R package. Our plan is to automatically add an “addons: apt:” entry to .travis.yml that installs the required system libraries.

Advanced

The advanced usage of tic is described in more detail in article Advanced Usage:

  • Options for pkgdown deployment
  • Using Travis CI Meta-information
  • Troubleshooting: Running tic locally
  • Troubleshooting: Enter into the Travis build
  • Writing custom steps
